results.adx_keywords: Social Media;Suits and Litigation (Civil);Computers and the Internet;Compensation for Damages (Law);Privacy;Cambridge Analytica;Facebook Inc;Meta Platforms Inc;California;United States
results.title: How to Claim Your Share of Facebook’s $725 Million Privacy Settlement
results.abstract: Anyone who had a U.S. Facebook account between May 2007 and December 2022 is eligible to apply, though payouts are likely to be small.

media.caption: The offices of Meta, Facebook’s parent company, in Menlo Park, Calif., in 2022.

results.byline: By Benjamin Mullin and Katie Robertson
results.title: BuzzFeed News, Which Dragged Media Into the Digital Age, Shuts Down
results.abstract: A quirky upstart that became a Pulitzer Prize-winning operation fell prey to the punishing economics of digital publishing.

media.caption: The New York headquarters of BuzzFeed, which started its news division in 2011.

results.title: They Saw the Horrific Aftermath of a Mass Shooting. Should We?
results.abstract: The crime-scene investigators are the ones who document, and remember, the unimaginable. This is what they saw at Sandy Hook.

media.caption: Detectives Art Walkley, left, and Karoline Keith and Sgt. Jeff Covello, crime-scene investigators for the Connecticut State Police.

results.adx_keywords: Workplace Hazards and Violations;Restaurants;Chefs;Sexual Harassment;Alcohol Abuse;Content Type: Personal Profile;Lynch, Barbara;Lynch, Barbara, Collective Inc;Menton (Boston, Mass, Restaurant);Boston (Mass)
results.title: Barbara Lynch, a Leading Boston Restaurateur, Is Accused of Workplace Abuse
results.abstract: The chef has spoken out against sexism and abuse, but many former cooks and staff members say she has verbally and physically harassed workers for decades.

media.caption: Barbara Lynch cooking in 2015. Twenty former employees said her fame and connections protected her from the consequences of her drinking and abusive behavior.
media.copyright: Erik Jacobs for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides;Movies;Baldwin, Alec;Hutchins, Halyna (1979-2021);Carmack-Altwies, Mary;Morrissey, Kari T;Reeb, Andrea;New Mexico;Santa Fe (NM)
results.byline: By Graham Bowley and Julia Jacobs
results.title: ‘Rust’ Prosecutors Are Dropping Charges Against Alec Baldwin
results.abstract: Mr. Baldwin had been charged with involuntary manslaughter after the gun he was practicing with went off on a film set, killing the cinematographer. The film’s armorer still faces charges.

media.caption: Alec Baldwin was charged this year in connection with the “Rust” shooting in New Mexico. “We are pleased with the decision to dismiss the case,” his lawyers said.

results.byline: By Julie Bosman, Mitch Smith, Jesse McKinley and Jay Root
results.title: Hundreds of Miles Apart, Separate Shootings Follow Wrong Turns
results.abstract: Two men appeared in courtrooms in different parts of the country on Wednesday, charged in shootings that came after minor missteps on everyday tasks.

media.caption: Andrew D. Lester, charged in the shooting of Ralph Yarl, pleaded not guilty on Wednesday.

results.title: My Transplanted Heart and I Will Die Soon
results.abstract: Organ transplantation is mired in stagnant science and antiquated, imprecise medicine that fails patients and organ donors.

results.title: Our Way of Life Is Poisoning Us

results.title: An A.I. Hit of Fake ‘Drake’ and ‘The Weeknd’ Rattles the Music World
results.abstract: A track like “Heart on My Sleeve,” which went viral before being taken down by streaming services this week, may be a novelty for now. But the legal and creative questions it raises are here to stay.

media.caption: Labels hope that fans will continue to prize the work of artists, including the real Drake, above that of A.I.-generated imitations.
media.copyright: Adam Riding for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Age, Chronological;Retirement;Work-Life Balance;Longevity;Content Type: Service;Pensions and Retirement Plans;Labor and Jobs;Social Security (US);audio-neutral-informative
results.title: What Is the Ideal Retirement Age for Your Health?
results.abstract: Average life expectancy has risen by 16 years since the national retirement age was set at 65. We asked health experts when they think people should stop working now.

results.byline: By David Waldstein and Benjamin Hoffman
results.title: With Las Vegas Land Deal, Athletics May Finally Leave Oakland
results.abstract: After years of tense negotiations to remain in the Bay Area, the A’s said they had reached a deal to acquire a stadium site near the Las Vegas Strip.

media.caption: Oakland Coliseum, the aging and often-empty home of the Athletics, is the fifth-oldest active stadium in Major League Baseball.

results.title: As Xi Befriends World Leaders, He Hardens His Stance on the U.S.
results.abstract: China has rebuffed calls to restart high-level talks with the United States, raising the risk of confrontation in contested areas like the Taiwan Strait.

media.caption: President Xi Jinping of China with President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva of Brazil last week in Beijing.

results.adx_keywords: Firearms;Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides;Gun Control;Self-Defense;Black People;Abbott, Gregory W (1957- );Banks, Omarian (d 2019);Hawley, Josh D (1979- );Giffords (Advocacy Group);National Rifle Assn;Florida;Georgia;High Point (NC);Kansas City (Mo)
results.byline: By Jack Healy, Glenn Thrush, Eliza Fawcett and Susan C. Beachy
results.title: In a Nation Armed to the Teeth, These Tiny Missteps Led to Tragedy
results.abstract: A workman knocking on the wrong door. A cheerleader mistaking another car for her own. Small errors can have large consequences in a nation bristling with guns.

media.caption: Lisa Johnson-Banks held a framed memorial of her son, Omarian Banks, in Riverdale, Ga., on Thursday. She said her son posed no threat on the March 2019 night that he was shot at the wrong apartment door.
media.copyright: Alyssa Pointer for The New York Times

results.adx_keywords: Ultramarathon Running;Cheating;Zakrzewski, Joasia;England;Great Britain
results.title: A 50-Mile Race, a Quick Car Ride and a Scandal at the Finish Line
results.abstract: An ultramarathoner was disqualified after covering part of a course in a friend’s car. She said it was a “miscommunication.” A rival had a different word: cheating.

media.caption: Joasia Zakrzewski competing in an ultramarathon in Norway in 2016.

results.adx_keywords: Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters;Rocket Science and Propulsion;Private Spaceflight;Space and Astronomy;Space Exploration Technologies Corp;Texas;Brownsville (Tex);Padre Island (Tex)
results.title: SpaceX’s Starship ‘Learning Experience’ Ends in Explosion
results.abstract: The first flight of the most powerful rocket ever was not the success that Elon Musk and his company hoped for, but the launch achieved several milestones toward future journeys.

media.caption: SpaceX’s Starship rocket successfully took off from a launchpad in Boca Chica, Texas, on Thursday, but exploded roughly four minutes into its flight.

results.adx_keywords: Private Spaceflight;Musk, Elon;Space Exploration Technologies Corp
results.byline: By Daniel Victor and Kenneth Chang
results.title: Starship Exploded, but SpaceX Had Reason to Pop Champagne Anyway
results.abstract: The four-minute flight ended in what the company called a “rapid unscheduled disassembly” — meaning it blew up. But there was much to learn from the flight, the latest step in SpaceX’s explode-as-you-learn approach.

results.adx_keywords: Presidential Election of 2024;United States Politics and Government;Primaries and Caucuses;Voting and Voters;Trump, Donald J;DeSantis, Ron;Republican Party
results.title: DeSantis’s Electability Pitch Wobbles, Despite G.O.P. Losses Under Trump
results.abstract: The former president’s rivals are seeking to tap into Republican frustration with recent election disappointments to urge a new face for the party in 2024, but it is proving to be a tough sell.

media.caption: Ron DeSantis has cast himself as more electable than Donald J. Trump, but for years Republican primary voters have cast ballots with their hearts, opting for hard-liners who lose in general elections.
media.copyright: Scott Eisen/Getty Images; Christopher Lee for The New York Times

results.title: Japan Has Millions of Empty Houses. Want to Buy One for $25,000?
results.abstract: With a shrinking population and more than 10 million abandoned properties, the country is straining to match houses with curious buyers.

media.caption: An akiya sat idle in Nagasaki, Japan, earlier this year.
